title: woman 37 weighing just 3
story: Exclusive: Woman, , weighing just  stone starving to death as eating causes agonyNicolette Baker, from Truro, Cornwall, has never been able to properly start her le due to the horric condition which means she cant eat without incredible pain Image: Greg Martin   Cornwall LiveByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Jan |commentsA woman who is literally aposstarving to deathapos with a rare condition needs a final £, before she can undergo treatment to save her le. Nicolette Baker was diagnosed with Superior Mesenteric Artery syndromenearly a decade ago - a condition which means that her Superior Mesenteric artery is compressing on her duodenum and kidney -causing her unimaginable pain when she tries to eat.A -year-old says eating something as small as a jelly baby feels like sheaposs aposfinished off a Christmas dinner apos and makes her intestine feel like itaposs aposgoing to burstapos.Over the years she had been misdiagnosed as anorexic and even force-fed, as her weight has dwindled to a terrying st. In March last year doctors told her she had aposdays to liveapos, meaning they would only offer her palliative care.  But defiant Nicolette wants to live and has already raised £, towards £, for surgery in Germany to relieve the pressure and pain her artery is causing. Nicolette said: The surgery is booked but I need to pay for the weeks Iaposll be spending in intensive care afterwards because my health is so poor. There’s only two weeks to go I’m really determined to keep going. I used to thinkI’m going to die I’m going to die but things have changed. Now I’ve actually been told I’m dying I don’t just want to surrender to that, I want to live and give something back to society.After being given days to live Nicolette became determined to defy doctorsapos predictions and earlier this month set up a GoFundMe where she opened up about how she is aposliterally starving to deathapos. Although Nicolette only received her diagnosis seven years ago, doctors believe she was born with the condition. Nicolette can recall having issues with her digestive system from as young as four years old, but it wasnapost until her late s that she would understand what was happening to her. She said: Eating a jelly baby feels like I’ve finished off a full Christmas dinner. As that jelly baby passes through my intestine the pain is incredible. It feels like a hose pipe with a blockage in it to the point where it is going to burst. She added: I remember throwing up liquid milk at four years old. I was just labelled as anorexic but when I eat it causes me so much pain.  The less I ate the less pain I’d have so I ended up losing quite a bit of weight and it was deemed to be a mental health problem.I was an inpatient at hospitals for years and I was force fed which only made the problem worse and caused me even more pain.The condition has completely robbed Nicolette of her le - she has been unable to start a family, have a career and was even forced to give up her beloved -year-old whippet, Eden. She said: I have always dreamed of my prince charming coming on a white horse but I don’t think that will happen. I had to give up my beloved dog because I couldn’t manage him anymore. The first thing I will do when Iaposve had the surgery is get him back. Before her health declined, Nicolette had worked part time in a hospice, until she could no longer even manage that - meaning she has no savings of her own to fall back on.  Now, as the condition holds her on the brink of death, it is a race against time to raise the final £, needed so she has secured her follow up treatment after her surgery on February . She said It would mean everything to raise the last £, I need so I donapost have that pressure hanging over me. Iaposm struggling with my breathing, my whole system is shutting down one by one. Iaposm desperate to make it through just so I can thank all the people who have so generously helped me get to this point. Nicolette will fly out on February  for preliminary scans ahead of the surgery at the end of the month. title: couple aged 50 60 spend
story: Couple aged  and  spend £, to have their baby togetherSharon Kollmar, , admitted people "couldnt understand" why she wanted to have a baby at the age of  with her -year-old fiancé, Gus, who is already a granddad-of-threeSharon was desperate for another baby and defies those who suggest shes too old Image: @sharonkollmar   CATERS NEWSByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments A mum who has given birth at -years-old admitted people thought she was crazy for spending £, to have a baby with her -year-old fiancé. Sharon Kollmar, from Long Island, New York, claims she was desperate to extend her family and have a baby with her fiance, Gus, , who is already a granddad. Sharon, , already has an -year-old son, Aiden, from a previous relationship, but always wanted more kids.After almost a decade of being single, she had started to look into sperm donors. But while explaining her quest to lelong friend and now fiancé, Gus, he suggested that the pair should strike up a relationship and try for a baby together. They ended up having to spend £,on an egg donor and IVF - they welcomed their daughter, Bayleigh Emerson, in September . Sharon said: I so desperately wanted more kids. People thought I was crazy for wanting to start all over again. Iaposd been to see fertility doctors who were dismissive because of my age and told me that although I still had eggs, the chances of me falling pregnant were slim. I was also still single. I was talking to my male friend about everything and out of the blue he said aposwhat about me apos Iaposd never even thought about it before but it seemed like a great idea. He had always been in my and my sonaposs le. So we started dating, and because I was around  and he was , we started trying to conceive straight away. We were trying for two years and hadnapost fallen pregnant, so we looked into donor embryos but the cut off age was . So we turned to donor eggs and found someone who matched my colourings and had fresh eggs, rather than frozen. The process cost us , and I went through rigorous physical testing and preparation. In January , when Sharon was , she underwent the embryo transfer which was successful on the first attempt. When she finally received the doctoraposs call confirming she was pregnant, she says it was the moment she had been waiting for for over a decade. Sharon and Gus, who is already a dad to his -year-old daughter and grandfather to her three children, welcomed their new addition on September , .Sharon added: My pregnancy was pretty textbook, although the baby was bigger this time around so I felt it a little more.But I love being pregnant. People couldnapost understand why we would want another baby at the age of  and . My friendsapos kids were graduating college and getting married. Some of my friends were even grandparents. Gus is even a grandfather and his daughter is . His grandkids are ,  and . So people had a hard time getting their head around it, but it meant the world to us. Sharon gave birth via C-section as there was meconium in her fluids and baby Bayleigh had flipped over out of the ideal delivery position. Sharon claims doctors also incorrectly predicted she would weigh lbs but she was born at a healthy lbs z. She said: Holding her in my arms was incredible. I love having a newborn. It is just as rewarding and satisfying as the first time. I think people thought I would regret it, but I would not change it for the world. When we brought her home and I placed her in my sonaposs arms, his eyes filled with tears and he told her that he had been waiting for her his entire le. It was so special. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Sharon and Gus still have four frozen embryos and love the idea of having another baby together. Sharon added: I want to give hope to people who thought their chance at parenthood was over. You need to have faith and live your own le, and not what your family and friends expect you to do. Just because you are a bit older, it doesnapost mean the door is shut.  People said was that it wasnapost fair to bring a child into the world at our age because we likely wouldnapost be alive to see them into adulthood or that weaposd be an embarrassment as old parents. But itaposs better to be born to old parents than not at all, and there is no guarantee that a -year-old that has a baby will see that child into adulthood as illnesses and accidents happen all the time. I always knew that I was going to have more children, even though I wasnapost sure how but I just knew that somehow it would all piece together and it has. I couldnapost be happier. news weird-news car-button-de-ices-windscreen-"Driving tip: How to defrost your windscreenByZahna EklundAudience writerLuke Chillingsworth:,  Jan |commentsWe all know how unforgiving the icy winter months can be, and for those of us that drive, scraping the ice off of your car windscreen in the early hours of the morning can be a real chore. But thanks to a tip from a driving school TikTok account named Driving Test Success @drivingtestsuccess, we no longer need to suffer in the freezing cold before we head to work, as it turns out you can actually get rid of the ice from inside your car as itaposs warming up. Experts at Driving Test Success say you can clear ice cover by simply activating your car windscreen fan, which will heat up the glass from the inside and help to melt the frost, the Express reports. In the companyaposs video, they explained: “Frozen windscreen  Put the temperature on high.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. “Put the front windscreen fan on max. The ice will start to melt from the heat. Wipe away excess water andthe fan to normal. While the tip might seem obvious to some seasoned drivers, several commenters on the video who were new to driving couldnapost believe theyaposd never seen the hack before. One commenter said: Wow, magic! The ice is gone. And another praised the account for all their help, as they wrote: Iaposve learnt so much thanks to your app!  But others were less impressed, as one TikTok user shunned the idea, stating: Wastes more fuel. Just get [out] and scrape it off you lazy so and so.” Driving Test Success is far from the first account to point out the easy de-icing trick either, as another video online from Clear View Driving said road users should use their demister before they start driving. They said: “Now donapost use your windscreen wipers or washers as that wonapost help. Turn on your front and rear demister. “The rear demister also heats up your side mirrors in most new cars. Butthe mirrors are not clear, make sure to clear them before you start driving. “Then, once itaposs done you can use your wipers.” And in the cold winter months, the AA has also encouraged road users to “turn on the warm air blower” and “heated mirrors” to clear frost cover quickly and safely.They explained: “Start the engine and turn on the warm air blower on the windscreen. Switch on the rear windscreen heater and heated mirrors,you have them. Turn on the air-con. Itaposs not just for summer – itaposll remove moisture from the air to stop the car from misting up. “Don’t use your hands to wipe misted-up windows – youaposll leave greasy smears and a diamond ring could scratch the glass. Use a lint-free absorbent clothnecessary. “Stay with your car the whole time while the engineaposs running.” What do you think is the best way to de-ice your car  Let us know in the comments below. title: four bedroom home goes sale
story: Four-bedroom home goes on sale for £.m - and it comes with its own tourist attractionA unique four-bedroom house has hit the market for a whopping £. million - and the lucky buyer will also bag a huge cave that tourists flock to visit every yearThe house seems unassuming from the outside Image: Jam Press Ryan NewberryByZahna EklundAudience writerRia Newman:,  Jan |commentsMost of us have a pretty good idea of what our dream home would look like, andyour idea of property perfection includes living next to - and owning - a tourist hotspot, you might just be in luck. A four-bedroom property in the city of Versailles in Missouri, USA, has just gone on the market for . million , and while the house may look unassuming from the outside, itaposs the additional land you get alongside the home that makes the purchase worth it. The house comes with a whopping  acres of land - and a historic cave that serves as a tourist attraction.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Named Jacobaposs Cave, the underground chasm was discovered by Jacob Craycraft in  and quickly became a popular haunt for tourists visiting the area.The location has been operational with a regular cave show since  and has stunning rock formations inside - including sea coral, and massive stalactites and columns. According to estate agents, the lucky buyer of the four-bedroom, four-bathroom house will be able to generate a generous annual income from visitors to Jacobaposs Cave - meaning you could happily live and work from your own home. The  acres surrounding the home includes a car park for visitors, while the remaining land could be used as a campsite to bring in even more revenue - although the current occupiers host three large gatherings for traders a year on the extra space. The listing reads: “With an available staff possessing knowledge of the business, you will be able to hit the ground runningyou should choose to continue maintaining this unique business and tourist attraction. “This opportunity is truly once-in-a-letime and has so much more potential you will have to see to fully appreciate.” And itaposs not all about the tourist attraction, as the house itself is a large two-storey property with plenty of space to raise a family or to relax after a long dayaposs work. Whataposs more, the home is nearby the famous Lakes of the Ozarks reservoir - which is a popular lake destination for both tourists and local residents, with more than , miles of shoreline to enjoy. The property is currently on the market with Justin Swast at Midwest Land Group. What do you think of the unique property  Let us know in the comments below. title: i tattooed forehead people think
story: I tattooed my own forehead - people think it went wrong but I love how it looksA woman decided to get her forehead tattooed and she actually inked it on her skin herself - but people were confused when they saw it, with some concerned about the unusual designNikki did the tattoo herself and says she loves it Image: @moodtoorude   TikTokByVerity Sulway:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments As tattoos go, many will say that anything on the head and face can be a risky decision. This is because everyone can see it and as such, thereaposs a chance it will affect your future career prospects, not to mention the possibility of it going wrong and you being unable to cover it up. But for TikTok user Nikki, it was a choice she was happy to make. In fact, she even decided to ink a design on her own forehead.The tattoo artist is adamant she loves it - but everyone  isnapost so sure, with several people questioning whether it had gone wrong. Some people were concerned and askedshe was okay, while some thought they were seeing things. Getthe newsyou want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Nikki had created a video to show off her transition contact lenses, but her face tattoo distracted viewers. Am I the only one that is seeing lines on her  one asked. Girl I thought you were turning into a vampire with the lines on your forehead and using the word apostransitionapos, joked another. It isn’t clear enough ma’am, that’s why everyone was asking, commented a third. Nikki received so many questions about her forehead tattoo, she created another video to explain the situation.  That video had a lot of people asking about my forehead - apparently it wasn’t clear enough that it’s a tattoo, she began. I tattooed it in grey wash so that it would have more of a shadowed effect. I did do it on myself. I’m a professional licensed tattooer of  years plus and I’ve had it for going on five years now. I wouldn’t recommend tattooing your own face unless you are confident to achieve what you want. She also explained that the design was inspired by the underside of a mushroom. I really liked how organic and wavy the lines were - some of them were shorter and some of them were longer, so that’s kind of the inspiration for this - the waviness, the organic flow of them is all intended, she said. But yeah it’s probably one of my absolute favourite tattoos. I have a seamless bodysuit - every inch of me pretty much is tattooed and it’s almost complete. But out of all of them, I love my little forehead crown tattoo. She added that the inking is not faded, contrary to popular opinion - it just looks dferent depending on how the light hits it. Her followers flocked to show their support, as one wrote: I think itaposs gorgeous and going with the underside of a mushroom is amazing but the most important thing is that you love it. You shouldn’t have to answer to anyone about anything, added another.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news weird-news man-eating-raw-meat--"Im only eating raw meat for  days to seeI dieByVerity Sulway:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments While some of us have been attempting veganuary, and more people than ever are turning to veggie meals in a bid to help the planet and save animals - one Instagram user has gone in the opposite direction.A US man has shockingly challenged himself to eat raw meat alone for  days to find out whether or not he will survive. He previously ate a plant-based diet but claimed to suffer from health issues because of it. So instead, heaposs been training his stomach to digest nothing but uncooked meat, including organs and he washes it down with raw animal milk and raw eggs. He claims his favourite meals include chicken breast, steak and swordfish and so far heaposs managed to avoid severe food poisoning. But worryingly he is risking contracting E. coli, salmonella and Shigella.Getthe newsyou want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here.He also faces further health issueshe fails to eat fruit and vegetables, including constipation, haemorrhoids and even scurvy.Posting stomach-churning photos of himself biting into raw flesh, the man has amassed a following online as they wait to see the effects of his bizarre diet. His Instagram page @therawmeatexperiment has .k followers, and the bio explains: Eating raw meat at Whole Foods every day until I die from bacteria SeeingI Live for  days or  years.  His aposcavemanapos diet has also seen him tuck into cow liver and camel milk and tearing into a steak with his teeth. No chewing involved, you can basically just place the cow flesh in your mouth and swallow it, he explained. Pretty tasty, half the cost of a steak, will probably be a weekly meal along with cod. Asked by a follower how he was feeling, he confirmed: Good, I like it so far and feel no reason to stop, no crazy changes either way though. On his th day, he revealed he was able to eat lb of mince in just five minutes - one of his favourites.  A brick of shredded cow and milk of the sheep. Ground beef has become my favourite meal, he said. Due to the low cost, ease of consuming a pound in like  minutes, gathering  calories of absorbable cow and digesting perfectly. He admitted cooked meat tastes a bit better though the raw stuff was growing on him. On day  he ate raw bacon, which one of his followers said looked like a skinned foot. For those concerned about how limited his diet is, he has explained he does occasionally eat potatoes, rice and cooked chicken. And heaposs claimed his pain has gone away since embarking on his new carnivorous diet. When I started eating steak and eggs for breakfast, instead of bagels and smoothies, I felt full for most of the day, and stable, instead of getting dizzy from a carb crash, my pain started to go away, he insisted. But doctors generally warn that eating a lot of raw meat is dangerousyou canapost be sure of the quality and what bacteria might be lurking beneath.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: mans creative job application method
story: Mans creative job application method gets the entire office talking about himJonathan Swt decided to think outside the box when he applied for a job on Instantprints marketing team - and his creative method has become the talk of the officeHis application got people talking ByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Jan |commentsWhen it comes to landing your dream career, you sometimes need to go above and beyond to land that all-important interview, and thinking outside of the box is definitely encouraged. One man who made sure he would stand out from the crowd was Jonathan Swt, who saw an opening for a position within the marketing department of Yorkshire-based printing specialists, Instantprint and decided to get creative with his application. The -year-old made his mark by recycling the companyaposs own flyers in a genius marketing stunt in the company car park - as he placed a flyer advertising his LinkedIn profile on every single car.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Marketing Manager Craig Wassell, who was doing the hiring for the position, noticed Jonathanaposs antics on CCTV when he was advised by security to take a closer look at what was going on. And he was so impressed that he decided to invite the man in for an interview. He said: When I looked out of the office window, I could already see that someone had been around leaving flyers on all the car windscreens, and upon closer inspection, it became apparent that the flyers more closely were, in fact, an application for the role I was hiring for. Naturally, we immediately invited Jonathan in for an interview. Craig also shared footage from the CCTV cameras, as well as a picture of the cars, on Twitter - where he admitted Jonathan has become the talk of the office thanks to his stunt. He wrote: We’ve been well and truly ‘flyered’ by a candidate applying for a #job in our marketing team. Every car in the car park is covered in flyers linking to the applicant’s LinkedIn profile! That’s definitely one way to stand out. He’s been the talk of the office since covering everyoneaposs cars in CVs. I love it when we get a #creativejobapplication. Instantprint received over  applications for the position, but thanks to Jonathanaposs stroke of creative genius, he became the lucky candidate to be offered the role and started his new job earlier this month. Craig added: “Jonathan’s application did more than grab my attention. It showed that he’d researched the brand and that he had the right attitude, creativity and sense of humour to fit the team perfectly. I can’t wait to see what ideas he brings to the table and to work with him in the future.” But Jonathan has admitted he canapost completely take credit for the idea, as he was inspired by a similar Instantprint employee who had bagged a position on the design team after having her photograph printed on the companyaposs roller banners. He said: “I remembered seeing Instantprint in the news a while back because a candidate had successfully applied for a design role by having her photograph printed on one of the company’s own roller banners, and thought ‘what a great idea!’ “I wanted my application to make a statement just like that one had and what better way than distributing  flyers with my face on around the company car park ” Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: dad carried away car bonnet
story: Dad carried away on car bonnet in bid to stop thief dies in hospitalIan McDonnell, , valiantly tried to stop the theft of his car in Clondalkin, Dublin, but was carried some distance and found lying in the road last Sunday" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _GettyImages-jpgth.jpg" width"" "" Gardai are investigating the death in DublinImage: NurPhoto via Getty ImagesByBradley JollyNews Wire:,  Jan |comments A dad who was carried on the bonnet of his car as a thief drove away has died of his injuries. Ian McDonnell, , was found on the road with le-threatening injuries at around .pm last Sunday, having been carried a signicant distance on the bonnet during the carjacking ordeal.He desperately tried to prevent the theft of his car, a grey Volkswagen Passat, at his business premises in Clondalkin, Dublin. Mr McDonnell died on Friday evening in nearby Tallaght University Hospital, Gardai said today. His we and children are being supported by police officers, Gardai added. A post-mortem will be carried out but officers continue to investigate the death.  The Volkswagen Passat was found in Greenhills, Dublin, on Friday and the recovered vehicle is due to be forensically examined. A second vehicle involved in the incident, a silver-coloured Toyota Aqua, which was stolen in Crumlin last Sunday, was found burnt out in Ballinascorney, Tallaght, on Tuesday. Gardai said this vehicle will also be forensically examined. Gardai in Clondalkin said they want to speak to anyone who was in the Robinhood Road area on the evening of January  between .pm and pm and who may have witnessed any activity which drew their attention, or who may have any video dashcam footage. Investigating Gardai said they are looking for any information on where either car was parked at any location, or whether either vehicle was seen in any petrol station or any other location over those days. Gardai are also seeking help from anyone who may have seen either of the cars in the areas of Ballymount, Walkinstown, Tallaght, Kylemore Road or Ballyfermot between .pm and pm last Sunday. Anyone with information is asked to contact Clondalkin garda station on  . title: madeleine mccann no1 suspect swapped
story: Exclusive: Madeleine McCann No. suspect swapped child abuse images with undertakerChristian Brueckner, the prime suspect in the disappearance of Madeleine McCann, swapped child abuse images with an undertaker. The mortician gave a full confession when quizzed by copsMadeleine McCann disappeared in Praia da Luz, Portugal on May ,  Image: METROPOLITAN POLICE AFP via GettByJon ClarkePatrick HillNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan The prime suspect in the Madeleine McCann case swapped child abuse images and depraved online messages with an undertaker. The mortician gave “a full confession” when quizzed by German police and admitted he was a “regular customer” of convicted paedophile Christian Brueckner. It is understood material he handed over to officers now forms part of evidence being used against Brueckner. The undertaker, also a convicted sex offender, cannot be named for legal reasons – but he has spoken to the makers of a new documentary about the case, being shown tomorrow night on German TV channel Sat.. The film’s lead investigator Jutta Rabe told the Sunday People: “I’m not sure what he paid but he confirmed they regularly swapped material, all of which he has handed over to detectives.  “We haven’t been able to confirmthey were business partners but he insisted he... has completely mended his ways.” The undertaker, who lives alone, said he was interviewed by the BKA – Germany’s FBI. Miss Rabe said: “He was given a choice, ‘You either admit it and help us then go into therapy or go to prison’. He chose co-operation.” She added: “He is terried of being attacked and horried of his family finding out.” Madeleine, three, vanished from an Algarve apartment in  while on holiday with her twin siblings and parents Kate and Gerry, of Rothley, Leics. In , Brueckner shared a string of sick messages with the undertaker, including some about snatching and imprisoning a toddler. Brueckner talks about making films to “document exactly how she is tormented”. The horrying Skype conversation was found when Brueckner was arrested for molesting his girlfriend’s daughter. He is now behind bars for offences including the  rape of a US widow in Praia da Luz – where Madeleine vanished two years later. German prosecutors say they have “concrete” evidence against him – and he is their only suspect in Madeleine’s case. But they also fear Breuckner has committed at least five other sex crimes, including the rape of an Irish woman, who was attacked in her Portuguese apartment in . The film reveals German police made a huge breakthrough when they unearthed a “partial fingerprint” of Breuckner’s which was found in the Irish victim’s flat. In the documentary, German prosecutor Hans Christian Wolters says he expects Brueckner to be charged with some of the crimes “imminently”. title: north korea launches seventh missile
story: North Korea launches seventh missile in just one month in aggressive show of forceKim Jong-un’s North Korea army launched the ballistic missile as the number of tests reached seven for the month of January - making it the busiest month on record for the stateKim Jong-un’s North Korea army launched the ballistic missile Image: EyePress News REX ShutterstockByDouglas Patient:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |commentsNorth Korea has launched yet another ballistic missile as the number of tests reaches seven this month - which is sure to cause tension across the world.Kim Jong-un’s hermit kingdom army launched the weapon into the sea off its east coast at around .am local timeon Sunday. It’s the nuclear-armed countryaposs seventh test this month which is a record for the state. The Japanese government said North Korea had launched a possible ballistic missile, while South Koreaaposs Joint Chiefs of Staff reported the launch of an unidentied projectile. The ballistic missile launch and the ones before it are a threat to our country, the region and the international community, Japanese government spokesperson Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno told a televised briefing.  This series of launches violate UN resolutions and we strongly protest this action by North Korea. Matsuno said thatthe projectile was a standard ballistic missile it is estimated to have reached an altitude of ,km, flown for  minutes, to a distance of km. It makes January the busiest ever for North Koreaaposs missile programme. Analysts say the country’s weapon tests are increasing and developing new capabilities despite strict sanctions and United Nations Security Council resolutions that ban the countryaposs ballistic missile tests. In an address ahead of the New Year, North Korean leader Kim Jong-un called for bolstering the military with cutting edge technology at a time when talks with South Korea and the United States have stalled.  Since then, North Korea has conducted a series of launches displaying a dizzying array of weapon types, launch locations, and increasing sophistication. From hypersonic missiles and long-range cruise missiles to missiles launched from railcars and airports, the tests highlight the nuclear-armed stateaposs rapidly expanding and advancing arsenal amid stalled denuclearisation talks. North Korea has not tested its longest-range intercontinental ballistic missiles or nuclear weapons since , but the countryaposs rulers suggested this month they could restart those activities.  Its latest launches included a test of two short-range ballistic missiles and their warheads on Thursday, and an update to a long-range cruise missile system was tested on Tuesday. The tests appear aimed at bolstering national pride ahead of several major North Korean holidays and sending a message of strength, said Le-Eric Easley, a professor of international studies at Ewha University in Seoul.The Kim regime hears external discussions of its domestic weaknesses and sees South Koreaaposs growing strength, he said.So it wants to remind Washington and Seoul that trying to topple it would be too costly. Pyongyang has defended the launches as its sovereign right of self defence. It says they are not directed at any specic country, but accused Washington and Seoul of having hostile policies”. Kim visited a munitions factory last week, where he called for an all-out drive to produce powerful cutting-edge arms”. He touted his devotion to smashing ... the challenges of the US imperialists and their vassal forces seeking to violate their right to self-defence, calling it the harshest-ever adversity”. title: parents forget baby supermarket drive
story: Parents forget baby at supermarket and drive home - as shopper finds him in trolleyA shopper was left gobsmacked after coming across a baby boy in a supermarket shopping trolley all by himself - after his parents reportedly made a massive mistakeThe baby was found in a trolley Image: NEWSFLASHByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Jan |commentsWhile out grocery shopping, customers at a store were left stunned by an unexpected find in a supermarket trolley.An unnamed shopper and several others came across a four-month-old baby boy sitting in a car seat in a trolley, with his parents seemingly nowhere in sight. As reported by The Sun, the childaposs parents had managed to drive home with their shopping before realising that they had forgotten the little boy.Locals found the tot at a supermarket in Lages, Brazil and were quick to inform security guards and the police.One shopper recorded the incident and in the clip, they could be heard asking the baby where his forgetful parents are. Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.They said: Have they left you here  Iaposve called security. Where are your mummy and daddy  Where  Where are your forgetful mother and father  When police arrived at the scene, the babyaposs parents had ed and they told officers how they had left the store, put their groceries into the car and drove home without putting their son in the vehicle as well. They added that they rushed back to the supermarket car park when they realised what they had done. Police officers concluded that the pair had suffered enough and decided not to take any further action against them. Thankfully the baby boy was fine and was filmed smiling by those who found him - despite being left on his own for a little while. Fort Atacadista, the supermarket company where the incident occurred, shared the following statement regarding the debacle: In a few minutes everything went back to normal and was resolved.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: new centre propels angus to forefront of farm innovation 2
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: ringlink issues a call for the next generation of farm workers
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: finished dry january
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. title: take part rspbs big garden birdwatch
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: moray mum who shed seven stone during pandemic to scale britains three highest mountains
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles.
